collected from intervening regions, that not only numerous errors of
detail have been committed, but general doctrines have been
propounded which the advance of Science has proved to be utterly
untenable _ As an example of the former kind, may be cited the
facts mentioned by Dr. J.D. Hooker (op cit), that of the New Zealand
varieties of <u>Oxalis corniculata</u>, one of the most widely disposed and
most valuable Flowering plants<s>,</s> in the world, no less than seven
or eight species have been made, neither of them supposed to be
identical with any belonging to the European Flora; whilst <s>Petris</s> <u>Pteris</u>
<u>aquilina</u> has a different name in almost every country in the world.
It has been through reliance on such ignorant determinations, most
of them proceeding on the notion that "the plants (or animals) of
newly discovered, isolated, or little-visited localities must
necessarily be new.", that the doctrine of the universal distinctness
of the species of the New World from those of the Old, and of those
of the Southern from those of the Northern Hemisphere, has attained
a very wide currency amongst Naturalists, and is still obstinately
persisted-in by some, in defiance of ample evidence to the contrary.
[<u>Note</u>."Thus as long ago as 1814, Mr. Robert Brown gave a list of 150 European
